reasoning: The critique targets the author’s use of the CES framework to generate quantitative implications (preferred rho range and early-stage SIE graphs) after emphasizing that CES-based extrapolation from economics/manufacturing is unreliable. That is moderately central, because those CES illustrations help support the author’s headline conclusion that compute bottlenecks likely don’t bind early; but the broader anti-bottleneck case also rests on multiple non-CES qualitative considerations (e.g., algorithmic efficiency raising effective experiments), so the position wouldn’t fully collapse if the CES usage were undermined. The critique has some bite: there is a tension between dismissing CES as unsuited for extreme extrapolation and then using it to support optimistic parameter choices. However, it’s not a full internal inconsistency, since one can coherently treat CES as a toy/sensitivity-analysis device while rejecting naive parameter importation from manufacturing; the author also explicitly frames the model as uncertain and uses it to show dependence on rho rather than to “vindicate” CES. Thus strength is limited. The critique is mostly correct in noting the apparent selectivity, but overstates by implying illegitimacy rather than ‘heuristic/illustrative use’. It is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: The paper selectively trusts the CES model only when it yields favorable conclusions
